Let's consider a complex-valued function \\( z(t) \\) that evolves according to the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}z = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant frequency. We investigate the influence of the Fourier transformation \\( F(z) \\) defined by \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty z(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\).

Can we reconstruct the original function \\( z(t) \\) at any initial time \\( t = 0 \\) from the Fourier transform \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) \\) observed at time \\( T \\) without knowing the initial form of \\( z(t) \\)?
Explanation: Given the evolution law \\( \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial t}z = i\\omega z \\), the form of the function in the frequency domain remains consistent. Thus, knowledge of \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) \\) uniquely determines the form of \\( z(t) \\) up to a constant phase factor, even at the initial time.
